Award.AbstractNarration:
The problem of model uncertainty has recently received widespread attention in applied mathematics, especially after being identified as a cause for the recent credit crisis. The investigator seeks to develop probabilistic tools for stochastic control problems under uncertainty, in particular in mathematical finance and related game theoretic problems. The focus is on situations of severe model uncertainty, where no reference probability measure can be constructed and, therefore, standard tools from stochastic analysis cannot be applied. The first part of this project studies the problem of superhedging for a European, possibly path-dependent option under model uncertainty as well as the fundamental duality between trading strategies and (possibly singular) risk-neutral measures. The second part is concerned with stochastic differential games of control and stopping and, in a special case, the pricing of American options under uncertainty. The third part investigates a nonlinear version of the Doob-Meyer decomposition, which is a step towards a theory of semimartingales and stochastic integration under uncertainty.

This project seeks a better mathematical understanding of model uncertainty. Its results help to resolve important questions of pricing, risk measurement, and hedging in mathematical finance. Moreover, the project leads to methodological developments in the theory of stochastic analysis and control.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Several questions from mathematical finance, optimal control and probability theory have been studied in this project.
The PI and his collaborators have analyzed how model uncertainty impacts the pricing and hedging of financial derivatives. This has led us to investigate the so-called martingale optimal transport problem and an extension of the optional decomposition theorem. We have also established a robust version of the fundamental theorem of asset pricing which relates a notion of market viability to the existence of pricing measures. Moreover, we have solved the problem of portfolio optimization under model uncertainty, thus showing how model risk impacts the decisions of long-term investors. Motivated optimization problems in finance, the PI and his collaborators introduced the so-called stochastic target games where one player tries to steer a stochastic process into a given target. These have led us to explore a geometric dynamic programming principle and related partial differential equations. We have also developed a nonlinear Snell envelope theory to analyze a stochastic game between a stopper and a controller which is related to American-style options. Contributions to probability theory include a general construction for nonlinear Levy processes and deterministic proofs for martingale inequalities.
The results of the supported research have been presented at domestic and international conferences, workshops and seminars, and have been published in leading journals. The project also led to the successful thesis of a graduate student. The PI has designed and taught new courses at Columbia University, incorporating material related to model uncertainty. He has also co-organized two conferences in mathematical finance and related topics at Columbia, and served the scientific community in various other capacities.
